title: Boris Johnson offering ‘lose-lose’ choice, says former Tory minister
text:
Justine Greening said that she would not stand at the next U.K. general election | Jack Taylor/Getty Images Boris Johnson offering ‘lose-lose’ choice, says former Tory minister Former Education Secretary Justine Greening says the Conservatives are ‘narrowing’ their appeal.

Boris Johnson would offer the U.K. public a "lose-lose" choice at a likely imminent general election, said former Conservative minister Justine Greening.

She told the BBC's "Today" Program that she would not stand at the next U.K. general election because her concerns that the Tories have become the next Brexit Party "in effect have come to pass."

Greening, who represents the Remain-voting constituency of Putney in South London, said: "I don't believe that the Conservative Party will offer people a sensible choice at the next election," because Prime Minister Boris Johnson is making voters choose between either "no deal or Jeremy Corbyn."

Johnson this weekend pledged to deselect any Tory MPs who failed to back the government in a vote this evening that would effectively take a no-deal Brexit off the table, and threatened a snap election next month if he loses the vote. This would mean those Tory MPs who rebel against the government would effectively be ending their political careers.

Asked about the change to the Conservative Party under Johnson she said: "My concern is that it is narrowing down its appeal, we can see that in the line it’s taking on MPs like myself who are simply at the end of the day representing their communities."
